reviews.content: Glendronach 12 year OB 1980’s v 2019 H2H(1)Glendronach 12 year 1980’s ,The Original Pure Highland Malt 40% 72371(2)Glendronach 12 year 1980’s , sherry casks,The Original Pure Highland Malt 40% 25645(3)Glendronach 12 year 2019,The Original Highland Malt 43% 9096NoseThe 1980’s (1) has more power than (2), the sherry bottle is a little distant in comparison to it’s sister bottle. The 2019 (3)is similar to (1), with the same DNA but less expressive.The clear winner here is (1) followed by (3) with the old sherried bottle (2) bringing up the rear.This smells creamy and reminds me of some old blends because there is some vanilla and lots of mango mixed with other white fruits. There is an almost industrial quality to it, like paint to be honest but it is ok and not off putting, just unusual?My initial impression is telling me that this needs water to open up, rather closed neat, there is a nice parma violet note in the mix, rose water and a little spice.Similar to (1) just not as pronounced, hints of vanilla but coming through is a juicy yellow plum note mixed with wisps of smoke, very nice.So the 1980’s original shares similar vapours with the 2019, the sherried 1980’s is more closed, being less expressive generally.The 1980’s (1) has more power than (2), the sherry bottle is a little distant in comparison to it’s sister bottle. The 2019 (3)is similar to (1), with the same DNA but less expressive.The clear winner here is (1) followed by (3) with the old sherried bottle (2) bringing up the rear.Palate-neatVery nice, on sweet candied fruit of lemon, apricot, peach and mango, lemon sherbet fizz.Slightly thin at first but way better than the nose suggested, a little cream but then a wave of fizzy sherry with a little peat and the balance is really good, tasty.There is no way this is 12 years old more like a 15/16 year old.This is a little smoother than it’s older siblings, more manufactured, engineered if that makes sense?Cream soda and a wave of sweet peat which I was not expecting, icing sugar, a little barley sugar and a lovely sweet spice notePalate (with 5 drops of water from a pipette)More lemon sherbet with a dash of water added, very good balance , still fizzy and lively.The water has brought more sweetness out, and a bubblegum noteStill sweet, with some barley sugar now and hints of lemon sorbetFinish (with water)Remaining sweet, fizzy and flavours are packed together tightly.The finish is full on lip smacking sherry, with parma violet on the tail.Similar to (1) sweet and fizzy basically.SummaryI kike the nose on (1) the best, the palate of the sherry cask 1980’s (2) is really good and a point or two infront of the others but the finish on the 2019 is a point in front of the other two older offerings.So for nose/palate/finish it looks like this :-Original 1980`s 89/88/87Original 1980’s sherry casks 86/90/87Original 2019 87/88/88A really enjoyable head to head, not much to separate them, all three were really tasty, no duffers here :)

Pedro Ximénez cask maturation holds a certain magic that is hard to explain, and combined with some fine Oloroso butts you get a true sherry monster of a single malt! On the nose, there is a nice interplay of intense sweetness and fruity acidity with pears, melons and hints of eucalyptus. After a rich brown sugar arrival, the taste gets more aromatic and slightly dry, featuring a pleasant oak complexity. The finish of GlenDronach 12 is long, delicate and chocolaty bitter. This malt is a keeper of consistently high quality and a better choice than Macallan.RATING: 4.0/5.0 stars ≙ 87 pts → FIRST-CLASS

N: Definitely the younger of the pair focusing on vanilla sponge, walnut cake, sugar syrup and passion fruits. This could pass for a youngish grain, given the simple sugars [Port Dundas #9452 for example].T: Young-to-youthful with an indistinct tastiness, or a tasty indistinctness if you prefer - simple stuff yet really well made. Revisited: same again, this time a little more fruity, but then again it’s somewhat this-and-that.F: Taste that highly-engineered, fast-yielding, blow-dried, wood-driven finish - namely vanilla oak with a soft chew.C: Yeah, it's good, very tasty but uneventful. Glendronach’s policy to switch from bourbon to sherry in the late ’90's maybe showing yet i only tried this once and that was a few years back, scoring it in the low 80’s. I believe Glendronach have switched back to sherry casks exclusively of late. Whether there’s any bourbon cask influence here or not, there’s plenty of modern 'tech' which makes it flawless though it only scores a C-Full report HERE.

reviews.content: The sherry hits you in the face, both fruity and very dry, somewhat spicy. Grapes, dried apricots, but also red fruits, raspberries, plums, greengage, papaya. Muscat grapes. Wet undergrowth. reviews.content: So today 03/11/2023 we are making a battle bottle glendronach 12 years from 2013..2016 and 2022...the differences are big...the 22er smells like modern weak bourbon briefly dipped in sherry. Quite a little sherry in taste..not round with herbs...the 2016 has more sherry in the smell and taste..rounder and a bit cucumber...already a bit better..also a little mezzo mix with spices.slightly tingling.good. ...the 2013 still has sherry old school...just as you know it...really great and full.milk chocolate, cocoa, spices, cola, cinnamon and orange...plums and raisins, that's how it should be... In summary, 2013 is really the best, and 2016 is good, even if there are only a few,...but to be honest, 2022 is really nothing more...I dumped it in the barrel.... Billy Walker just didn't have any broken pieces there and bad barrels leave behind, or do the new managers have to learn first? Maybe that's why he left there. Hopefully a super distillery doesn't collapse. 2013 88p....2016 86p...2022 74p

reviews.finish: The finish now shows oak and sherry, drier than in the mouth and nose. A nice interplay between sweet and dry, medium long.

reviews.content: Quite nice, felt a little unbalanced, still good quality.
reviews.nose: Stewed plums. Brandy. Brasil nuts. Mahogany. Light paprika. Nutmeg. Red fruits. Bit of floral with time.
reviews.taste: Dry wood. Raisins. Prunes. Macadamia. Burned pecans.
reviews.finish: Medium. Espresso. Bitter tannins. Bit of sweet figgy notes.

reviews.content: yes .... beautiful twelve-year-old malt, not over-complex but offers more than many others at the age of twelve. Quite delicious

reviews.content: A good entry level sherried dram and a perfect introduction to the Glendronach core range. Value (£35) : 8/10

reviews.taste: Pleasant mouthfeel, sweet on the palate with cinnamon and ginger as well. Some delicious milk chocolate turn into a drying oak spice
reviews.finish: More chocolate and oak spice here. Medium in length

reviews.taste: full-bodied, honey coated raisins, dates, complex vanilla, vanillin and bitter vanilla tea, oak and a hint of pepper mint far back.
reviews.finish: Long, sweet and spicy. Sherry spices, christmas cake, allspice and bitter wood.

reviews.content: This basic Glendronach will make a digestif of choice.
reviews.nose: Oak, sherry, oak, vanilla, caramel, oranges.
reviews.taste: Sweetness, caramel, vanilla, sherry influence, oak, fruity notes (oranges, red fruits).
reviews.finish: Quite long and dry, with peppery notes.

reviews.content: One of the best Scotch standards ever.

Glendronach The Original Aged 12 Years, 43%. I wasn’t rating whisky when I went to the distillery and tasted this for the first time. 50ml miniature consumed May 2022. Bold golden yellow orange borderline. Aroma is manhood ...what? NO. Damn autocorrect. Mango and apricot (both dried), biscuit, ginger and apple tea. Musty oak. The tropical fruit is so dried out it’s become a little meaty. Trail mix. Body is lightly oily. Taste is salty up front, some peppermint comes through the salt, always stays fresh salty and minty, spirit-led and not so sherry cask influenced as some will have you believe (at least on the palate). Some chocolatey char starts to come through on the finish, some bitter oak, some chilli. Spiced linger. Not bad. I believe I had a similar impression of this last time. It’s fine and certainly not over-sherried, which is always a good thing in my book, but it’s as though the maturation casks haven’t taken the edge off the spirit despite the years. The aroma is very good but the palate doesn’t catch up. Good nevertheless. 3.4/81
Light green fruit, citrus, slightly bitter texture and oily, malt, miscellaneous spice

reviews.taste: Wood, nuts, oak, dried fruit, chocolate… light bitter…

reviews.taste: Medium body. Medium fat. A little dry. Lack a bit of scale and stuff. The woods dominate.
reviews.finish: On the fruity notes of sherry.  Suitable length.  Retro-olfaction on the old wood.

reviews.taste: w/o water - sweet, spicy arrival. Covers the tongue. Sherry-wine and canned fruit development.w/ water - spicy arrival. Sweet fruit development.
reviews.finish: w/o water - lightly dry fruit finish, medium-long.w/ water - savoury, spicy, warm finsih. Long.

reviews.content: Bottled 2019
reviews.nose: Dried red fruits and forest fruits, milk chocolate, honey, raisins, a bit of vanilla, a bit of dried plums, ripe orange, ripe apples, light notes of nut nougat, powdered cocoa, a tiny handful of dried herbs, forest moss, delicate notes of wood
reviews.taste: More fresh, green apples combined with a lot of wine notes, dried forest fruits, a handful of dried herbs, dried plums, a small pinch of cinnamon, slightly spicy, nutty, a bit citrusy and malty, milk chocolate, honey, vanilla, delicate oak notes
reviews.finish: Long, pleasantly nutty, slightly spicy, dark chocolate with sherry notes at the end

reviews.nose: Strongly noticeable notes of sherry, dried plums, raisins, ripe apples, slightly citrus, vanilla, honey, milk chocolate, a pinch of dried herbs, a little nutty at the end
reviews.taste: Lots of sherry notes at the beginning, a pinch of cinnamon, dark chocolate, a handful of dried herbs, vanilla, orange peel, apple, spicy, a little bitterness of oak
reviews.finish: Long with notes of sherry, dried herbs, spicy, oak bitterness

reviews.content: Another sample from Drinks By The Dram. This is a baby sherry bomb, both immediately alluring and complex enough to maintain your interest. A wonderful invitation into the world of sherry maturation as well as the Glendronach core range. Highly recommended.
reviews.nose: My first thought is PX sherry, which is not to say overwhelming, but as in there is no question about what we’re dealing with here. Raisins, prunes, sloes, berries and dark fruits. Lovely oak, cedar, varnish, and leather overtones. Chocolate and vanilla coming in and out of focus. Not overly expressive, but it’s all in there and it’s lovely.
reviews.taste: An initial blast of sweet brown sugar and rich vanilla cream. Rich and oily body. Becoming more bitter, like dark chocolate, before transitioning to ripe fruits and hazelnut.
reviews.finish: The PX sherry returns as a soft reminder, bringing a dry and spicy oakiness to the pleasingly long finish. Latterly a spirity glow emerges and beckons you to lift the glass again.

reviews.content: A solid beginner Sherrymalt, but not more. He has too little tension in my mouth.
reviews.nose: instant orange juice, orange marmalade, quince marmalade, honey, chocolate, red berries, pears, raisins
reviews.taste: Juicy oranges, jam, dark chocolate, quickly becoming espresso, a touch of cinnamon, ginger, white pepper, creamy - generally less tension, more pulpy aroma, not well accentuated; little sweet
reviews.finish: getting dry quickly, medium in length, warm and spicy

reviews.content: 2016 VERSION

Best part of this dram is the lovely nose, however it does follow through with a reasonable taste. Bitter off putting notes it’s a bit old school compared to all the new sherry cask products out there at the moment. To its credit the distillery character shines through without cask dominance.

reviews.taste: Rich fruity, raisins, classic sherry finish , bitter chocolate notes, plum fruits. Figs dates and cigars.
reviews.finish: Pepper and spice.

reviews.content: The whisky tastes incredibly good for the price, it is sometimes available for 30-35 euros. One of my standard whiskys. A slightly more expensive but almost equivalent alternative would be the Tamdhu 12. Edit: Unfortunately, the quality decreases with each new bottle, especially the difference between the first and second was immense. I still have two in stock, I hope Glen Dronach gets back to his old form. Edit 2: I opened a new (old) bottle, this one tastes like it used to. Now I'm sure the quality has gone down with new bottlings. The last of my bottles is a current one, I will report here.

reviews.taste: Again, mainly sherry, followed by vanilla, chocolate, dried fruit and lemon.
reviews.finish: Relatively long, but less pronounced, vanilla, nut and sherry.

reviews.content: A good entry whisky, wanna try once more

reviews.taste: spicy, caramel, orange, subtle sherry aromas, ripe apple mild and medium to slightly intense in body, absolutely flawless

reviews.content: RATING: 86pts – |83 – 86 (B) → Good| — Not a “must”, but a nice-to-have.
reviews.nose: The nose is sweet and beautifuly sherried with notes of brown sugar, milk chocolate, dark fruits and ripe melon.
reviews.taste: The taste is pleasant and silky with a profile of strawberry jam, dark fruits, chocolate and some delicious spices.
reviews.finish: The finish is medium lenght and feels very soft with notes of spicy oak, gentle milk chocolate and eucalyptus.

reviews.content: wonderfully sweet, tasty and fruity Sherrydram, without edges but good to drink, 46% would have done him good, anyway: absolute PLV cracker
reviews.nose: Sherry !, Sweet, dark fruit jam, blackberries, nuts, currants, oranges, sweet fruit compote with vanilla sauce, no alcohol, barely oak, sweetened and caramelized
reviews.taste: Oranges, light bitterness, latte, sweetness, sherry, getting drier, no alcohol noticeable, very mild, a bit weak,
reviews.finish: Medium long finish, with some coffee, little oak, milk chocolate, lasting sweetness and nuts

reviews.content: Just a good whisky for a normal price. Nice to enjoy, but nothing special.
reviews.nose: Immediately a clear scent of red fruit, soft raisins and chocolate. There is also a sweet scent of honey and caramel
reviews.taste: The taste is soft with an obvious sherry flavor. Think of raisins and figs, but also a clear bitter undertone of chocolate. There is a soft pepper in the background, which provides a nice depth.
reviews.finish: Short to medium long, that pepper is present again. In addition, a deeper bitter taste of chocolate and coffee emerges here

reviews.content: I think the most amazing thing about this whisky is the very dynamic finish. The nose gets an interesting twist with the water, but the bitter edge and more pepper tips over the balance of the palate.The notes are from LH30406 2014/05/13 14:17 bottle
reviews.nose: A bit prickly on the nose. Immediately sweet with prunes and raisins and dried figs. Also ripe cherries. Whiff of wood smoke. Sugar syrup. Just a hint of saw dust speaks of the oak.Water: cherry pie; With time - lovely cappuccino note; milk chocolate; the dried fruits are still there. Lovely.
reviews.taste: Sweet arrival, drying in the middle. Typical Christmas cake spices with a lovely dried fruit sweetness.Water - bitter oranges and more oak and pepper
reviews.finish: Sweet, dry fruits, nutmeg and clove, then bursts into fruit sweetness and goes into very balanced wood dryness. The sherry influence lingers on.

reviews.content: I was pleasantly surprised by this one. Unlike some other younger, sherry-heavy whiskies I've tried, this one was easy to enjoy pretty quickly. The first glass took about 10-15 minutes after pouring to settle down, but every glass over the successive days thereafter was pretty much ready within a few minutes after pouring. I really enjoyed it, and I think it's a great example of a younger sherry-heavy whisky that shows solid maturation. For what it's worth, I recommend it!
reviews.nose: Rich red fruits (cherries and raspberries) and dried fruits (prunes, figs, papaya), candied orange peels, a touch of raisins and leather, brown sugar and soft toasted oak, sweet baking spices (coriander, powdered ginger, and cinnamon), and some dusty dry-herbal note (licorice and ginseng root).
reviews.taste: Toasted oak, butterscotch and malt, dried fruits (raisins and dates), red fruits (cherries and raspberries), cinnamon with a touch of brown sugar added, candied orange peel, and ginger and brown sugar black tea.
reviews.finish: Cocoa, bitter-sweet herbal (licorice and ginseng pastels), dark coffee, and orange peel and oak and sherry tannins.

reviews.content: What can I say - I like him very much! On some days even more than the bigger 15-year-old brother. A great, fruity entry into the sherry whisky world, which is still very pleasant even after years. Wonderful vanilla, dark fruits and honey, simply harmonious from the nose to the finish. Is my absolute favorite among the whiskys up to 40€.

Finally managed to try this. At this price point, it is well worth a visit by lovers of sherried whisky. Easy-drinking, as the palate is certainly the highlight here. Due to the gap in production, bottlings prior to 2014 are certainly much older than 12 years, so check your local stores.
reviews.nose: Initially sharp. The astringency does not come from the alcohol, but rather due to oak spice and sherry. Brighter, zestier fruits, compared to the older standard bottling. Not sweet at all. Lemon drops, bees wax, dry sherry. With some air and a drop of water prunes and figs are emerging.
reviews.taste: Full bodied oakiness and quite Christmas cakey. Still not as sweet as the Revival or the Parliament, yet typically Glendronach! Menthol, bitter chocolate, raisins.
reviews.finish: Medium-long. Pretty standard for a sherried Highlander. Moderately tannic and a little licorice coat the tongue for a minute or two.

reviews.nose: Sweet, soft, nuts, apricot, orange marmalade
reviews.taste: Sweet, creamy, orange, vanilla, slightly sparkling
reviews.finish: Mild, some oak, oranges, dry, light pepper.

reviews.content: Always great. Intense, hard, worth every penny. An excellent entry into Glendronach's core range.
reviews.nose: Dark sherry, high-ripe pear, behind it warm custard. In between, always ginger.
reviews.taste: Spiced wine, red berries, some oak and vanilla. Roasted coffee on the palate.
reviews.finish: Long and warm, lots of spice and dry sweetness.

reviews.content: a full and round malt that is quite complex, soft and round, also brings some darker aromas but is not killed, the finish is then rather dry.
reviews.nose: Fruit, Honey, Dried Fruit, Wood / Wort, Earth ... Herbs, Ethereal,  first full fruits not completely dark, like mirabelles and grapes, later darkening, the slightly earthy woody spice is always present and is carried by the forest honey, sometimes more times less. In between a few vanilla and citrus flavors shine through like limes, behind are still a few herb notes
reviews.taste: fruity, spicy, sweetish, vanilla, astringent, quite full flavor that brings dark fruity spiciness from the barrel, but still sweet and creamy remains, a little custard was stirred somewhere.
reviews.finish: medium-long, spicy, bitter, dried fruits, herbs  The finish is then rather adstringend and characterized by the spice, but at the end everything is fruity and sweeter here.

reviews.content: The 2013 version is actualy 18 years oldhttp://wordsofwhisky.com/glendronach-is-a-lot-older-than-the-label-says/
A good daily dram, even for beginners, has a lot to discover
reviews.nose: Creamy, sherry, vanilla, vanilla crisp, white chocolate, oak, coconut, fresh banana
reviews.taste: White pepper, moderately sweet, oak, buttery, vanilla
reviews.finish: Short-medium length, Spicy, Drying

reviews.content: Very sweet on the nose, fruity vanilla. Oaky, but sweetness dominates. Balanced upon arrival, taking a turn toward dry wood in the finish. Excellent value for money.

Tasted in a series at a recent tasting night. Not a sherry bomb by any means, but some of the typical sherried notes are still there. Despite the NCF, pretty watered down and not too exciting. This is one case where you are much better off pursuing the 18yo, even if it costs significantly more.
A must for the price. But of course not all the complexity of top quality malts.  In fact a good start for anyone who wants to start progressing in the wonderful world of whisky.
reviews.nose: Nice mixture of malted and sherryed notes, hot pastries and orange jams.
reviews.taste: Rich and thick with honey, orange and yellow fruit jam, some chocolate and some exotic spices.
reviews.finish: Long and strong; we find all the components of the mouth.

reviews.content: Usually, the WB valuation of entry whiskys is somewhat low - in my opinion, "experience" and snobbery play an important role. The Glendronach, however, gets what it deserves. Refined wood aromas, beautiful sherry sweet, an excellent whisky to get to know and to introduce people to uncomplicated, beautiful single malt. Come on, he could use a little more punch, 46 or 48 percent had more depth. There is a sulfur in the aftertaste that didn't necessarily have to be - but come on - three decades!
The finish is shorter than hoped for, but this is a very decent whisky. Good price-quality.
reviews.nose: Orange fruit, chocolate, malt. Vanilla sweetness, caramel. Light oak notes. Fudge, raisins and dates.
reviews.taste: More tingly than the sweet nose would have predicted. Sweetness comes back soon, though, with chocolate and vanilla, nice fresh fruitiness. Dried orange.
reviews.finish: A slight bitter note prevents an overly sweet finish. Warming, with that orange fruit still hanging on. Good stuff.

reviews.nose: walnuts, caramel, toffee and just a hint of orange.
reviews.taste: starting of soft with malt and vanilla. Leading to more complexity with red fruits and rose hip jam.
reviews.finish: vanilla and caramel fading slowly into a nice medium-long finish.

reviews.content: Lovely selected sherry casks for a reasonable price.

Quite sweet on the nose with honey and sherry fruits. In addition, green and yellow apples and a great note of vanilla. Fruity aroma, but nowhere near as complex as its older brothers. Slightly peppery in the mouth, further fruity and also a little bit spicy. Unfortunately also a little watery and out of round. The finish is typical Glendronach: fruity, spicy with fine, bitter aromas. At 12 years of age, however, it was still relatively short and mild. But you can already taste where it goes. Length: 4/10 Nice entry into the Glendronach range with the classic distillery character. Maybe a bit too simple compared to other 12 year olds. Grade: 2
Nosing: seasoning, oak, dark, ripe fruits, flowery heather, sweetness with sherry  Tasting: Spicy, sweet, full, fruity, sherry  With water: Milder, lighter

I particularly like the fact that the impression of coffee from light milk coffee to espresso is built up and developed over the entire drinking experience.  A very nice introduction to the sherry world of GlenDronach and definitely miles more complex and intense than the Hielan.
reviews.nose: Sweet dried fruits, dates, figs, red grapes and sweet malt. Then strengthen orange marmalade and fine roasted aromas, like a light coffee with a dash of milk.  The oak of the European sherry barrels carries the flavors along with the welcome drink strength of 43%.
reviews.taste: Sweet, soft and creamy - the alcohol is well integrated and only brings some heat to the esophagus.  Honey, sherry fruits, milk chocolate, the orange marmalade now tends to apricot strawberry.  The oak is also there, the coffee is now made from stronger beans and served without milk.
reviews.finish: Surprisingly spicy and dry. Mixed nuts, espresso and distant raisins. Then some pepper and cream caramel. The sweetness wrestles with the spice and no impression wins the upper hand permanently.

reviews.content: Matured in Oloroso and Pedro Ximenez ex-sherry casks. Non-chill filtered. Not coloured. Thick slow slowly forming primary legs. Mid-size slow secondary legs. Trailing droplets.
reviews.nose: Sweet: vanilla, brown sugar, honey, confectionery. Fruity: dried fruit: raisin, plum, fig; fresh fruit: plum; citrus: ripe orange. Cereal: malt, hay. Winey: sherry. Floral: fragrant, heather. Feints: leather, tang, wax. Spicy: ginger, baking spices, liquorice. Oily: cream. Nutty: hazelnut, walnut. Rich. Full body: harmonious. Water turns up nutty notes.
reviews.taste: Sweet: caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, syrup. Fruity: dried fruit: raisin, prune, fig, date; stone fruit: plum, peach, cherry. Spicy: ginger, salted caramel, liquorice note, cake. Cereal: malt. Winey: sherry. Woody: oak. Nutty: walnut, hazelnut. Full body: smooth, mouthwatering. Rich: impactful. Water turns up fruity notes.
reviews.finish: Long. Sweet: confectionery. Fruity: dried fruit; stone fruit; fresh fruit. Spicy: ginger, Christmas cake. Nutty: walnut. Woody: oak. Winey: sherry. Cereal: hay. Rich: delicious. Full body: dry. Water turns up fruity notes.

reviews.content: The promises made by the nose become fullfilled in the taste. Too bad the finish remains slightly behind.
reviews.nose: Wood (oak). Very malty and lots of vanill;a. Some pineapple and organge. Chocolate and hints of butterscotch and raisins.
reviews.taste: Delicious sweet from the chocolate and oranges. Fresh but also warming.
reviews.finish: Ornages. Also hints of vanilla and some fruit candies. Rather short and dry.

reviews.nose: Raisin, chocolate, pepper, plum, floral
reviews.taste: Raisins, nuts, chocolate, prunes, multi
reviews.finish: Chocolate, nuts, spices, multi

reviews.content: Blind tasting The taste and finish are more beautiful than the smell. A great thing, mild but probably CS and a bit older. After the resolution, it must be said, a 12 year old Sherry standard that is second to none. Excellent price-performance ratio.
reviews.nose: Amber, sherry, thick and oily. Tobacco, nuts (walnut and almond), raisins, dates, even a little tropical (coconut)
reviews.taste: Light and mild, rum raisins, dates, coconut, papaya, physalis, very light tobacco. Class!
reviews.finish: Long! Oily, fruity and spicy. Top.

reviews.content: Aroma: sweet, strong sherry, spices, oak, ginger, vanilla  Taste: Sherry, dark fruits, some oak  Finish: Medium long, weak, slightly bitter
Too Spicy

The fragrant and soft fruity and nutty flavors like raisins and prunes are delicious. Red Bright and heavy It starts off heavy and ends sourly, which is really appealing ㅋㅋ The spiciness at the end seems to change, but then suddenly stops.
One of the best 12-year-old whiskies I know and reasonably priced.
reviews.nose: Fruity with grapes, pears and plums. Fresh PX sherry and oloroso sherry notes. A hint of vanilla. A nice smell for the summer.
reviews.taste: Smooth with sweet fruits, a lot of sherry, coffee, chocolate, spices and oak. After letting it breathe in the glas, it opens up and reveals liquorice.
reviews.finish: Long-lasting with a lot of oak, dark chocolate, coffee and spices. This then turns towards old, but sweet sherry. Amazing, for a 12-year-old whisky.

reviews.content: Awesome companion to a lovely cheese platter!

Very equal whisky (although the smell is the greatest advantage), sherry accents definitely in the foreground at every step. Favorite among sherry bombs in that price range below 200 PLN (especially that closer to 150). Definitely worth recommending for those looking for a good introduction into the intense flavors of red fruits.
reviews.nose: intense mix of sweetness - vanilla, honey, sherry and delicacies
reviews.taste: sherry in the foreground, ginger, oak barrel, even more roots, even more sweets - malt and plum jam
reviews.finish: long, sweetness gives way to dark chocolate, but at the same time it's creamy and smooth

reviews.nose: sherry, marzipan, dry wine, bourbon red apple and vanilla, yellow melon, then caramel, oak trace
reviews.taste: sherry, vanilla, toffee, sweet, milk chocolate, almonds, spices, wood, licorice, gooseberry
reviews.finish: long, very good, raisins, vanilla, almonds, sherry, red fruit, dry wine

reviews.nose: delicate sherry notes, lots of vanilla, dried fruit and chocolate,  light cinnamon and cloves flavors
reviews.taste: beautiful composition of sweetness and acidity
reviews.finish: slightly dry, mid-length great sherry flavor

reviews.content: An outstanding and balanced highland whisky
reviews.nose: Apricot, raisins, vanilla, sweet, winey
reviews.taste: Subtley spicy, sweet sherry, creamy, toffee, a bit of oak
reviews.finish: Spicy and soft

reviews.nose: Sherry, vanilla
reviews.taste: Sherry, hazelnut
reviews.finish: Sherry

reviews.nose: Relaxing sherry, dried grapes, and barrel wood.
reviews.taste: Dried fruit and sweetness.

reviews.content: Solid sherried dram. It’s nothing unique, but I mean that in a good way this time. Compared to an Aberlour 12 for instance, this is easier to drink while keeping the all good parts of the sherried profile. Happy to finish this bottle, solid 84.
reviews.nose: A very ‘clean’ sherried profile, with the usual notes. Raisins, dried figs, dates, Christmas cake, marmelade, cinnamon, cloves, some vanilla. Nothing unique pops out, but the balance is nice and it works.
reviews.taste: Sweet and not oily/viscous at all (so a nice way of saying the texture is watery). Christmas cake, quite some spice (cinnamon, cloves, allspice), fresh and dried red fruits (raisins, fresh plums), brownies, a bit of dark chocolate.
reviews.finish: Medium long and sweet, like after a bite of cake with fruit marmalade and chocolate frosting.

reviews.nose: Raisins, chocolate, ripe, cinnamon, Christmas spices, distinct sweetness
reviews.taste: Kako, raisins and dark fruits, tangerines + Christmas spices, caramel - vanilla - creamy
reviews.finish: medium and warm, pleasant

reviews.content: Nose: At first a bit harsh due to the wood and sherry notes (allow the whisky in the glass to breathe a little and this impression is softened), pear, citrus fruits (orange), dry  Taste: full-bodied oak taste, beautiful sweetness, delicate bitter chocolate, raisins  Finish: medium in length, the tannins of the oak occupy the mouth for a long time, typical sherry whisky with dark fruit
A medium heavy spicy whisky, in which the dark notes dominate like dark fruits and wood, not too complex, but not boring either.
reviews.nose: Notes from a blind tasting:  Dark fruits in alcohol, pineapple, orange peel, cinnamon and clove, wet leather, malt sugar, forest honey, sherry keg. Spicy, warming, dark. Medium heavy, harmonic, not too complex nose, more barrel-heavy, dark notes dominate
reviews.taste: Honey sweetness, well integrated, tingling alcohol, caramelized malt sugar, pickled fruits, wet saddle leather, spicy and warm.  Oily mouthfeel, marked salivation, slightly astringent, but harmonious.
reviews.finish: Medium.  Moist cedar wood, pickled dark fruits, fine-sour chocolate, light alcohol, spicy, warm and medium heavy,  Harmonious, slightly barrely, oily, dark and slightly bitter.

reviews.content: Nice sweet and sour sherry, rich, nutty with a spicy kick with strong vanilla reminds me redbreast 12 unfortunately don't have a bottle now.
reviews.nose: dark flavours, sweet, some spices on the nose, vanilla
reviews.taste: sour dominant, spice kick, a bit watery, on second sip more of full velvety mouthfeel
reviews.finish: dry finish, tannic, short-medium finish, nice oak, nuts,

reviews.content: Creamy taste, a combination of apples, toffee and delicate vanilla with notes of sherry, dark fruit and dark chocolate. Lots of fruitiness.

In recent years, various distilleries have continued to release "Sherry cask" flavored whisky. But my personal standard for "Sherry cask", It's this bottle of Gelendronach 12yo. No way to convince me to buy those whiskies if they don't beat this 12 yo in the taste of "Sherry Cask". This bottle has a solid foundation and tells the world what a "Sherry cask" whisky should look like, I hope this persistence can be maintained forever. The total taste is 86 points, and the price adds 1 point, for a total of 87 points.

Glendronach 12 YO The Original Category: Single Malt Manufacturer and bottler: The Glendronach Distillery (Brown - Forman) Region: Highlands Fortress: 43% Volume: 700 ml Bottling date: 07/13/2021 Barrel type: Pedro Ximénez & Oloroso Sherry Casks Min. exposure: 12 years Filtration: none Dye: no Nose. Baked apples, pears, plums and Seville oranges, apricot pit, dried banana slices, cocktail cherry, chocolate Christmas cake with raisins, almonds, hazelnuts and a mixture of spices (cinnamon, cloves, ginger, nutmeg, star anise). For a 12 year old, very beautiful, powerful, memorable aromatics, as well as a good balance of sweetness and acidity from fruits and spiciness from spices. Taste. The sweetness of cane sugar at the beginning is replaced by a fleeting pepper, clove, ginger “wave”, which, in turn, already gives way to a richness of fruit overtones (baked pears, dried apples, plum and apricot jam, orange peel with cinnamon, brown raisins, figs) , vanilla cream and nuts. Dessert, but with an appropriate bitterness, silky, with a moderate density (I would still add 3% to the fortress), dryish, but in moderation, rich in various nuances and an extremely pleasant taste that can be enjoyed for a long time, finding new shades. Aftertaste. Dry. Medium duration. Raisins, dried apricots, ginger, apricot kernel, hazelnuts. Outcome. A very decent 12. One of the best representatives among non-peat "Scots" of mass production of this age. A real “sherry bomb”, which, despite its youthful years, already demonstrates the hefty potential of properly selected barrels. The richness of taste, aroma and aftertaste is guaranteed to you. Whisky, with which you can catch a buzz under any circumstances. Rating: 85 out of 100.

2019 vintage. You can feel the youth ness off the 12yo, but it is balanced with some very fine oak. so the defects are covered by the flavour of the sherry. But you can still find the character of the distillery. Very good work!
reviews.nose: Not too strong, but fresh. Fruitness like apricot and plum. Some pineapple can water. A little acidity and alcoholic note. Very juicy, with apparent maltiness in the back, creamy vanilla also. The stewed fruits at the bottom of the cup. From time to time, oakiness shining through.
reviews.taste: Mid-sweet fruitness. In the middle, the maltiness and the creamy vanilla appear. The immatured menthol is well balanced by the maltiness. The body is oily and sticky. Then hazelnut appears. Some clove and cinnamon sharpness in the finish.
reviews.finish: Very dry oakiness coating my mouth, apricot sweetness, clove. Mid-long.

reviews.content: For those who enjoy deep and dark sherry flavors, this whisky makes for an excellent daily dram. While it's not a long-aged expression and has some hollow spots in the flavor profile, it still offers an enjoyable experience.
reviews.nose: Right after opening, there's a strong alcohol presence with a somewhat unrefined sherry nuance. The sherry influence feels deep but slightly underdeveloped, like it hasn’t fully matured. Notes of dried raisins, leather, and a barnyard-like mustiness (which adds an intriguing, almost mysterious character). Additional layers of dried blueberries, dried apricots, black pepper, and warm spices emerge.
reviews.taste: It starts with a touch of black pepper and spice, followed by an unpolished bitterness from the alcohol. The flavors soon transition into dried apricots and mixed berries, before evolving into a honeyed, caramel-like sweetness with hints of almonds.
reviews.finish: The finish is medium in length, beginning with berry-like notes before shifting towards a nutty character, where almonds and hazelnuts become dominant. The lingering nuttiness adds a toasty, satisfying conclusion.

reviews.content: Very standard sherry barrel flavor, very cost-effective

reviews.nose: From the very start the sweetness is what hits you. A fruity sweetness, that is reminiscent of some sort of fruit liquor or fruit cake. With apricot as protagonist. This is followed by some Oloroso notes serving a vinous aroma. The nose ends sweet as well with hints of milk chocolate.
reviews.taste: The fruitiness hasn't gone far. Raisins, cranberries and orange zest set the tone for this dram. Some peppery and woody balance out the delicate floral taste of apricot blossom and coffee blossom.
reviews.finish: The finish os slightly grassy and woody, bringing to mind some ginseng and nutmeg

reviews.nose: Sweet lord! From the very start I can smell some oranges and milk chocolate. Sweet but also fruity. Also a strong vanilla note reaches the surface. It brings back the memory of freshly baked hotel cake.
reviews.taste: Sweet again. Chocolate and vanilla comes to the mind immediately. Creamy and full mouth feel. Custard is present as well. In the back there is an oaky note from the Oloroso cask.
reviews.finish: Medium and dry finish. At the very end you get a nutty character.
